title: 107_hr4818
content: The Act titled "Mortgage Loan Consumer Protection Act" aims to simplify and improve disclosure requirements. The Mortgage Loan Consumer Protection Act aims to improve disclosure requirements by excluding certain escrows from finance charge calculations and providing clearer disclosure statements for closing costs. The Mortgage Loan Consumer Protection Act amends the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act to require lenders to itemize fees and costs for credit extensions. This includes Total Lender Fees, Prepaid Items like interest and escrow deposits, and All Other Costs Paid At Closing. The Act aims to harmonize Good Faith Estimates and Settlement Statements for clearer disclosure of closing costs. The Mortgage Loan Consumer Protection Act amends the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act to require lenders to itemize fees and costs for credit extensions. This includes Total Lender Fees, Prepaid Items like interest and escrow deposits, and All Other Costs Paid At Closing. The Act aims to harmonize Good Faith Estimates and Settlement Statements for clearer disclosure of closing costs by delineating the 3 types of charges specified under section 4(a)(2). The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act is amended to require final settlement statements to be provided at least 2 days before settlement. Additionally, the Act prohibits markups and undisclosed lender fees. The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act is amended to require disclosure of all lender fees and prohibit markups and unearned fees. Additionally, enhanced consumer assistance is provided. SEC. 5. ENHANCED CONSUMER ASSISTANCE: Amends the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act to include explanations on cost-efficiency of refinancing a mortgage loan and options for paying fees. Section 10 of the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act of 1974 is amended to include new subsections regarding the liability of servicers for fees and charges arising from failure to make timely payments, restrictions on receiving fees for force-placed hazard insurance, and requirements for timely crediting of escrow funds. The servicer for a federally related mortgage loan must return any remaining escrow funds to the borrower within 21 days after the loan is paid in full, or sooner if the borrower provides written notice at least 7 days before the payment. The servicer must return any remaining escrow funds to the borrower within 21 days after the loan is paid in full. Failure to comply results in liability to the borrower for the unreturned amount, plus a penalty. SEC. 7. ENFORCEMENT OF RESPA CONSUMER PROTECTIONS. Amends the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act of 1974 by adding a new section on damages and costs. The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for damages and costs for non-compliance with specific sections. Damages to the borrower, additional damages up to $2,000 per loan, and legal costs are outlined for successful actions. Additionally, enforcement provisions are updated by removing subsection (f) from section 6. The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for damages and costs for non-compliance with specific sections. Section 6 (12 U.S.C. 2605) is updated by removing subsection (f), and section 10 (12 U.S.C. 2609) by removing subsection (d). Jurisdiction of Courts and Statute of Limitations under section 16 (12 U.S.C. 2614) is expanded to include sections 9, 10, or 13, with a 3-year statute of limitations for violations. The amendments made by this Act will take effect after a 180-day period from the enactment date.
